content: i read an article about some teens that found and returned dog tags to a man after they had being missing since WWII. it got me thinking about my grandfather that was in WWII, i was going to ask him if i could have them, but when i asked if he still had them he said that they had been stolen, along with his bag, right after he came back from germany after the war was over. he said the only thing that he came home with was the clothes on his back and the camera that he had in a pawn shop. my question is, is there any way that i can get them for him again? i'd like to give them to him as a birthday present if they could. i know that to alot of service men and women they are very important to them and i think that my grandfather would like to have them back even though they wouldn't be the original ones i think that they still would be cherished.
reply: i read an article about some teens that found and returned dog tags to a man after they had being missing since WWII. it got me thinking about my grandfather that was in WWII, i was going to ask him if i could have them, but when i asked if he still had them he said that they had been stolen, along with his bag, right after he came back from germany after the war was over. he said the only thing that he came home with was the clothes on his back and the camera that he had in a pawn shop. my question is, is there any way that i can get them for him again? i'd like to give them to him as a birthday present if they could. i know that to alot of service men and women they are very important to them and i think that my grandfather would like to have them back even though they wouldn't be the original ones i think that they still would be cherished.
title: lost dog tags...

content: You'll need his service #, branch of service, command, and his full name. There are outfits that make the stainless(or aluminum?) dog tags. Check in the military magazines, or on the i-net. Nice thought...you are right that they have importance with many GIs and family members. - LHA-3 Rusty, USN 1977-1985
reply: You'll need his service #, branch of service, command, and his full name. There are outfits that make the stainless(or aluminum?) dog tags. Check in the military magazines, or on the i-net. Nice thought...you are right that they have importance with many GIs and family members. - LHA-3 Rusty, USN 1977-1985
title: lost dog tags...

content: Those can be purchased easily enough. All you'ld need his his name, seral number, look on his discharge papers for that and religion. The newer ones don't have the notch. If you live near a college, ROTC units might have the machine needed to engrave them.

content: My Father was a Marine in WWII. He saw action in the Pacific Theater. I carry one of his dog tags in my wallet to this day. On the back of it is a finger print. Anybody out there ever seen or heard of that before?

content: LHA_3Rusty Member Posted Sun 22 March 2009 10:31 PM Hide Post Oh, WELCOME to the military.com internet family...I look forward to your contributions, and to being able to help you as well. take care...guard the fragile flame of Liberty jealously, lest it be snuffed out, and Darkness prevail over us. - LHA-3 Rusty Posts: 820 | Registered: Thu 14 August 2008 wow, thank you!! that made me tear up a little. i have never served, tried but they wouldn't take me, because i wouldn't get married and had no one to take my children while i was gone. i went so far as to pass the asfab test with a score of 63, but when i came back from the test and we were making plans of what would happen next, that's when they told me that because i was a single mother that i had those 2 choices. i do my little part in donating cash to dav and vfw when ever i can, unfortunatly in the past couple of years it hasn't been as much as i would have liked. i was injured at work and instead of helping me and getting me get better so i can work without pain and problems they just fired me, but enough about my lil bellyaches. i find other lil ways to show my love and appreciation by spreading around emails, posts on my myspace page, never watching movies with non supportive actors or directors...lol!! and i keep all in my heart and prayers. i wish that i knew more ways that i could help and show my love for all that our troops do for us every day!! content: quote: Originally posted by LHA_3Rusty: His service records may well be at the Nat'l Personnel Records Center in Saint Louis, Mo. I think it's the Anthony J. Celebreze Bldg...been awhile since I got my medical and service records from them, so forgive me if I'm not 100% correct! Age HAPPENS, ya know... i found wherer you were refering to unfortunatly on July 12, 1973, a disastrous fire at NPRC (MPR) destroyed approximately 16-18 million Official Military Personnel Files. The affected record collections are described below. Branch Personnel and Period Affected Estimated Loss Army Personnel discharged November 1, 1912, to January 1, 1960 80% Air Force Personnel discharged, September 25, 1947, to January 1, 1964 (with names alphabetically after Hubbard, James E.) 75% (my grandfather was in the p's) No duplicate copies of the records that were destroyed in the fire were maintained, nor was a microfilm copy ever produced. There were no indexes created prior to the fire. In addition, millions of documents had been lent to the Department of Veterans Affairs before the fire occurred. Therefore, a complete listing of the records that were lost is not available.
quote: Originally posted by LHA_3Rusty: His service records may well be at the Nat'l Personnel Records Center in Saint Louis, Mo. I think it's the Anthony J. Celebreze Bldg...been awhile since I got my medical and service records from them, so forgive me if I'm not 100% correct! Age HAPPENS, ya know...
reply: i found wherer you were refering to unfortunatly on July 12, 1973, a disastrous fire at NPRC (MPR) destroyed approximately 16-18 million Official Military Personnel Files. The affected record collections are described below. Branch Personnel and Period Affected Estimated Loss Army Personnel discharged November 1, 1912, to January 1, 1960 80% Air Force Personnel discharged, September 25, 1947, to January 1, 1964 (with names alphabetically after Hubbard, James E.) 75% (my grandfather was in the p's) No duplicate copies of the records that were destroyed in the fire were maintained, nor was a microfilm copy ever produced. There were no indexes created prior to the fire. In addition, millions of documents had been lent to the Department of Veterans Affairs before the fire occurred. Therefore, a complete listing of the records that were lost is not available.

content: i read an article about some teens that found and returned dog tags to a man after they had being missing since WWII. it got me thinking about my grandfather that was in WWII, i was going to ask him if i could have them, but when i asked if he still had them he said that they had been stolen, along with his bag, right after he came back from germany after the war was over. he said the only thing that he came home with was the clothes on his back and the camera that he had in a pawn shop. my question is, is there any way that i can get them for him again? i'd like to give them to him as a birthday present if they could. i know that to alot of service men and women they are very important to them and i think that my grandfather would like to have them back even though they wouldn't be the original ones i think that they still would be cherished.
reply: i read an article about some teens that found and returned dog tags to a man after they had being missing since WWII. it got me thinking about my grandfather that was in WWII, i was going to ask him if i could have them, but when i asked if he still had them he said that they had been stolen, along with his bag, right after he came back from germany after the war was over. he said the only thing that he came home with was the clothes on his back and the camera that he had in a pawn shop. my question is, is there any way that i can get them for him again? i'd like to give them to him as a birthday present if they could. i know that to alot of service men and women they are very important to them and i think that my grandfather would like to have them back even though they wouldn't be the original ones i think that they still would be cherished.

content: quote: Originally posted by LHA_3Rusty: His service records may well be at the Nat'l Personnel Records Center in Saint Louis, Mo. I think it's the Anthony J. Celebreze Bldg...been awhile since I got my medical and service records from them, so forgive me if I'm not 100% correct! Age HAPPENS, ya know... i found wherer you were refering to unfortunatly on July 12, 1973, a disastrous fire at NPRC (MPR) destroyed approximately 16-18 million Official Military Personnel Files. The affected record collections are described below. Branch Personnel and Period Affected Estimated Loss Army Personnel discharged November 1, 1912, to January 1, 1960 80% Air Force Personnel discharged, September 25, 1947, to January 1, 1964 (with names alphabetically after Hubbard, James E.) 75% (my grandfather was in the p's) No duplicate copies of the records that were destroyed in the fire were maintained, nor was a microfilm copy ever produced. There were no indexes created prior to the fire. In addition, millions of documents had been lent to the Department of Veterans Affairs before the fire occurred. Therefore, a complete listing of the records that were lost is not available.
quote: Originally posted by LHA_3Rusty: His service records may well be at the Nat'l Personnel Records Center in Saint Louis, Mo. I think it's the Anthony J. Celebreze Bldg...been awhile since I got my medical and service records from them, so forgive me if I'm not 100% correct! Age HAPPENS, ya know...
reply: i found wherer you were refering to unfortunatly on July 12, 1973, a disastrous fire at NPRC (MPR) destroyed approximately 16-18 million Official Military Personnel Files. The affected record collections are described below. Branch Personnel and Period Affected Estimated Loss Army Personnel discharged November 1, 1912, to January 1, 1960 80% Air Force Personnel discharged, September 25, 1947, to January 1, 1964 (with names alphabetically after Hubbard, James E.) 75% (my grandfather was in the p's) No duplicate copies of the records that were destroyed in the fire were maintained, nor was a microfilm copy ever produced. There were no indexes created prior to the fire. In addition, millions of documents had been lent to the Department of Veterans Affairs before the fire occurred. Therefore, a complete listing of the records that were lost is not available.
title: lost dog tags...

content: i read an article about some teens that found and returned dog tags to a man after they had being missing since WWII. it got me thinking about my grandfather that was in WWII, i was going to ask him if i could have them, but when i asked if he still had them he said that they had been stolen, along with his bag, right after he came back from germany after the war was over. he said the only thing that he came home with was the clothes on his back and the camera that he had in a pawn shop. my question is, is there any way that i can get them for him again? i'd like to give them to him as a birthday present if they could. i know that to alot of service men and women they are very important to them and i think that my grandfather would like to have them back even though they wouldn't be the original ones i think that they still would be cherished.
reply: i read an article about some teens that found and returned dog tags to a man after they had being missing since WWII. it got me thinking about my grandfather that was in WWII, i was going to ask him if i could have them, but when i asked if he still had them he said that they had been stolen, along with his bag, right after he came back from germany after the war was over. he said the only thing that he came home with was the clothes on his back and the camera that he had in a pawn shop. my question is, is there any way that i can get them for him again? i'd like to give them to him as a birthday present if they could. i know that to alot of service men and women they are very important to them and i think that my grandfather would like to have them back even though they wouldn't be the original ones i think that they still would be cherished.
title: lost dog tags...

content: You'll need his service #, branch of service, command, and his full name. There are outfits that make the stainless(or aluminum?) dog tags. Check in the military magazines, or on the i-net. Nice thought...you are right that they have importance with many GIs and family members. - LHA-3 Rusty, USN 1977-1985

content: LHA_3Rusty Member Posted Sun 22 March 2009 10:31 PM Hide Post Oh, WELCOME to the military.com internet family...I look forward to your contributions, and to being able to help you as well. take care...guard the fragile flame of Liberty jealously, lest it be snuffed out, and Darkness prevail over us. - LHA-3 Rusty Posts: 820 | Registered: Thu 14 August 2008 wow, thank you!! that made me tear up a little. i have never served, tried but they wouldn't take me, because i wouldn't get married and had no one to take my children while i was gone. i went so far as to pass the asfab test with a score of 63, but when i came back from the test and we were making plans of what would happen next, that's when they told me that because i was a single mother that i had those 2 choices. i do my little part in donating cash to dav and vfw when ever i can, unfortunatly in the past couple of years it hasn't been as much as i would have liked. i was injured at work and instead of helping me and getting me get better so i can work without pain and problems they just fired me, but enough about my lil bellyaches. i find other lil ways to show my love and appreciation by spreading around emails, posts on my myspace page, never watching movies with non supportive actors or directors...lol!! and i keep all in my heart and prayers. i wish that i knew more ways that i could help and show my love for all that our troops do for us every day!!
